shoes: Van Gogh painted several still lifes of shoes or boots during his Paris period.
Van Gogh has placed the shoes within a specific spatial context: namely, the red-tile floor of the Yellow House.
this "still life of old peasants' shoes" may have been those of Patience Escalier, whose portrait Van Gogh executed around the same time, late summer 1888.

toledo: it portrays Toledo, the city where he lived and worked for most of his life
The Met's painting belongs to a tradition of emblematic city views and derives its potency precisely from the representational license it takes
As with El Greco's finest portraits, its approach is interpretive rather than documentary: it seeks to portray the essence of the city rather than to record its actual appearance

Toledo is the city portrayed, where he lived and worked for most of his life. The Met's painting belongs to a tradition of emblematic city views and derives its potency precisely from the representational license it takes. As with El Greco's finest portraits, its approach is interpretive rather than documentary: it seeks to portray the essence of the city rather than to record its actual appearance

portrait: The style of this portrait, with its simplified forms and flat color, blends aspects of Symbolism and Fauvism and is typical of Picabia's maturing style as he began to try his hand at different approaches.

mistinguett: The model for the picture, Mistinguett, was a successful actress and singer, and was one of Picabia's first famous friends from the entertainment industry (she was at one time the lover of Maurice Chevalier).

palestinian: The Palestinian, upon the usurpation of his homeland, had to distinguish himself professionally and through his conduct in order for him to find his place in life.
Life for the Palestinians did not stop at any place in spite of its harshness, limitations and the arbitrariness of the laws.

Palestinian popular life persisted in the face of all kinds of oppression, whether in the areas which became under Israeli occupation within occupied Palestine (1948), or those areas occupied by Israel in 1967 (the West Bank & Gaza).
Thus, Palestinian living became subject to the changes which imposed a new pattern for the behavior and life of Palestinians, in the social, cultural, economic and political senses.
In effect, the Palestinian community remained cohesive and with a presence, maintaining its heritage and traditions.
The life of the Palestinian communities continued with its happy and sad moments- through a wedding or a new-born, or through the return of someone abroad.
The Palestinian toiled in all available arenas and in all professional specializations.
a new pattern of Palestinian life began to prevail inside the camp and outside of it.
aiding the Palestinian individual to re-evaluate what happened and, likewise, to ponder what could happen.

The Palestinian, upon the usurpation of his homeland, had to distinguish himself professionally and through his conduct in order for him to find his place in life. The Palestinian toiled in all available arenas and in all professional specializations. Life for the Palestinians did not stop at any place in spite of its harshness, limitations and the arbitrariness of the laws. Palestinian popular life persisted in the face of all kinds of oppression, whether in the areas which became under Israeli occupation within occupied Palestine (1948), or those areas occupied by Israel in 1967 (the West Bank & Gaza). Thus, Palestinian living became subject to the changes which imposed a new pattern for the behavior and life of Palestinians, in the social, cultural, economic and political senses. In effect, the Palestinian community remained cohesive and with a presence, maintaining its heritage and traditions. The life of the Palestinian communities continued with its happy and sad moments- through a wedding or a new-born, or through the return of someone abroad. A new pattern of Palestinian life began to prevail inside the camp and outside of it, aiding the Palestinian individual to re-evaluate what happened and, likewise, to ponder what could happen.

this piece portrays her as a fully developed, sexually mature woman.
Madonna was another painting of which Munch made many reproductions. This painting depicts Mary, Mother of Jesus, and portrays her as a fully developed, sexually mature woman.

sexually mature woman: Mary, Mother of Jesus. Unlike the typical depiction of Mary as a fully clothed, chaste woman, this piece portrays her as a fully developed, sexually mature woman

virgin: The Virgin is seated broadly and holds the half-naked infant on her lap.

infant: holds the half-naked infant on her lap.

joseph: Joseph on the left is eclipsed by the two protagonists.
He sits at an angle facing them, on a seat lower than the Virgin's.
He looks up and focuses on a point somewhere outside the picture, as if reflecting on the words he has just read in the open book on his lap.
He holds his reading glasses absent-mindedly and is clearly lost in thought.
The portrayal of Joseph as a young and vigorous man, in contrast to the traditional elderly figure, is in line with the dictates of Counter-Reformationist principles.
